newsitem.title: UNITED NATIONS: Ukraine says Chernobyl still costs $1 billion a year.
newsitem.headline: Ukraine says Chernobyl still costs $1 billion a year.

text.p: President Leonid Kuchma told an international Earth Summit on Tuesday his country was spending a billion dollars a year to combat the aftermath of the Chernobyl nuclear disaster 11 years ago.
"Eleven years after the catastrophe, we still feel its after-effects, and not us alone," he said, referring to the spread of nuclear fallout from the disaster to other countries.
Kuchma said the nuclear power plant that exploded in 1986 would be decommissioned by 2000 and Ukraine had taken major steps to ensure such a disaster could not happen again.
"I would like to emphasise that Ukraine has radically reformed its state system of ensuring nuclear and radiation safety with due account of broad international experience," he said.
"From the former Soviet Union, we have inherited a resource-and energy-wasteful economy, when natural resources were considered to have no cost and to be practically inexhaustible," Kuchma said.
The resource consumption of Ukrainian products was 2 to 3 times higher than the world standard while energy waste was 6 to 9 times higher than the world level.
